org.threadly.litesockets.tcp

Class SSLClient

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.threadly.litesockets.Client
      • org.threadly.litesockets.tcp.TCPClient
        • org.threadly.litesockets.tcp.SSLClient

  • public class SSLClient
extends TCPClient
    This is a generic SSLClient that can be used to create an encrypted connection to a server. By default it will not check the servers certs and will only do TLS connections.

    • Constructor Detail

      • SSLClient

        public SSLClient(java.lang.String host,
                 int port)
          throws java.io.IOException

        This is a simple SSLConstructor. It uses the default socket timeout, and very insecure cert checking. This setup to generally connect to any server, and does not validate anything.

        Because we are making the connection this is always a "ClientSide" connection.

        Parameters:
        host - The host or IP to connect to.
        port - The port on the host to connect to.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - An IOException is thrown if there is a failure to connect for any reason.

      • SSLClient

        public SSLClient(java.lang.String host,
                 int port,
                 javax.net.ssl.SSLEngine ssle)
          throws java.io.IOException

        This simple SSLConstructor. It allows you to specify the SSLEngine to use to allow you to validate the servers certs with the parameters you decide.

        Because we are making the connection this is always a "ClientSide" connection.

        Parameters:
        host - The host or IP to connect to.
        port - The port on the host to connect to.
        ssle - The SSLEngine to use for the connection.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - An IOException is thrown if there is a failure to connect for any reason.

      • SSLClient

        public SSLClient(java.lang.String host,
                 int port,
                 javax.net.ssl.SSLEngine ssle,
                 int timeout)
          throws java.io.IOException

        This constructor allows you to specify the SSLEngine to use to validate the server certs with the parameters you decide. It also allows you to set the timeout values.

        Because we are making the connection this is always a "ClientSide" connection.

        Parameters:
        host - The host or IP to connect to.
        port - The port on the host to connect to.
        ssle - The SSLEngine to use for the connection.
        timeout - This is the connection timeout. It is used for the actual connection timeout and separately for the SSLHandshake.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - An IOException is thrown if there is a failure to connect for any reason.

      • SSLClient

        public SSLClient(java.lang.String host,
                 int port,
                 javax.net.ssl.SSLEngine ssle,
                 int timeout,
                 boolean doHandshake)
          throws java.io.IOException

        This constructor allows you to specify the SSLEngine to use to allow you to validate the servers certs with the parameters you decide.

        Because we are making the connection this is always a "ClientSide" connection.

        Parameters:
        host - The host or IP to connect to.
        port - The port on the host to connect to.
        ssle - The SSLEngine to use for the connection.
        timeout - This is the connection timeout. It is used for the actual connection timeout and separately for the SSLHandshake.
        doHandshake - This allows you to delay the handshake till a later negotiated time.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - An IOException is thrown if there is a failure to connect for any reason.

      • SSLClient

        public SSLClient(java.nio.channels.SocketChannel client,
                 javax.net.ssl.SSLEngine ssle,
                 boolean clientSSL)
          throws java.io.IOException

        This constructor is for already existing connections. It also allows you to specify the SSLEngine to use to allow you to validate the servers certs with the parameters you decide.

        Because we are making the connection this is always a "ClientSide" connection.

        Parameters:
        client - The SocketChannel to use for the SSLClient.
        ssle - The SSLEngine to use for the connection.
        clientSSL - Set this to true if this is a client side connection, false if its server side.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - An IOException is thrown if there is a failure to connect for any reason.

      • SSLClient

        public SSLClient(java.nio.channels.SocketChannel client,
                 javax.net.ssl.SSLEngine ssle,
                 boolean clientSSL,
                 boolean doHandshake)
          throws java.io.IOException

        This constructor is for already existing connections. It also allows you to specify the SSLEngine to use to allow you to validate the servers certs with the parameters you decide.

        Because we are making the connection this is always a "ClientSide" connection.

        Parameters:
        client - The SocketChannel to use for the SSLClient.
        ssle - The SSLEngine to use for the connection.
        clientSSL - Set this to true if this is a client side connection, false if its server side.
        doHandshake - This allows you to delay the handshake till a later negotiated time.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - An IOException is thrown if there is a failure to connect for any reason.

      • SSLClient

        public SSLClient(TCPClient client,
                 javax.net.ssl.SSLEngine ssle,
                 boolean clientSSL,
                 boolean doHandshake)
          throws java.io.IOException

        This constructor is for already existing connections. It also allows you to specify the SSLEngine to use to allow you to validate the servers certs with the parameters you decide.

        Because we are making the connection this is always a "ClientSide" connection.

        Parameters:
        client - The TCPClient to use for the SSLClient.
        ssle - The SSLEngine to use for the connection.
        clientSSL - Set this to true if this is a client side connection, false if its server side.
        doHandshake - This allows you to delay the handshake till a later negotiated time.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - An IOException is thrown if there is a failure to connect for any reason.

    • Method Detail

      • isEncrypted

        public boolean isEncrypted()
        This lets you know if the connection is currently encrypted or not.
        Returns:
        true if the connection is encrypted false if not.

      • doHandShake

        public org.threadly.concurrent.future.ListenableFuture<javax.net.ssl.SSLSession> doHandShake()

        If doHandshake was set to false in the constructor you can start the handshake by calling this method. The client will not start the handshake till its added to a SocketExecuter. The future allows you to know when the handshake has finished if if there was an error. While the handshake is processing all writes to the socket will queue.

        Returns:
        A listenable Future. If a result was given it succeeded, if there is an error it failed. The connection is closed on failures.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • setThreadExecuter

        protected void setThreadExecuter(org.threadly.concurrent.SubmitterExecutorInterface sei)
        Description copied from class: Client
        This is used by the SocketExecuter to set the ThreadExecuter this client is supposed to use. The ThreadExecuter works in a single threaded manor to keep all the client operations in order. This might need to be exposed to your package but in general You should not be assigning this or changing it.
        Overrides:
        setThreadExecuter in class Client
        Parameters:
        sei - the ThreadExecuter to use for this client.

      • setSocketExecuter

        protected void setSocketExecuter(SocketExecuterBase ce)
        Description copied from class: Client
        Sets this client to the specified SocketExecuter. This happens when the client is added to the SocketExecuter. This method should not be overridden.
        Overrides:
        setSocketExecuter in class Client
        Parameters:
        ce - the SocketExecuter to set for this client.

      • writeForce

        public void writeForce(java.nio.ByteBuffer buffer)
        Description copied from class: Client
        This write basically forces the client to go over its maxBufferSize. This technically does not have to be implemented by the client and can be dangerous if done incorrectly.
        Overrides:
        writeForce in class Client
        Parameters:
        buffer - the ByteBuffer to write to the client.

      • getRead

        public java.nio.ByteBuffer getRead()
        Description copied from class: Client
        Whenever a Reader is called for this client a .getRead() should be called.
        Overrides:
        getRead in class Client
        Returns:
        a ByteBuffer of a read for this client.

      • setReader

        public void setReader(Client.Reader reader)
        Description copied from class: Client
        This sets the Reader for the client. The Reader is called every time a new read is added to the client Each time a Reader is called it should call .getRead() *once* on the client
        Overrides:
        setReader in class TCPClient
        Parameters:
        reader - the Reader interface to set for this client.

      • enableSNI

        public static void enableSNI()
        Java 7 introduced SNI by default when you establish SSl connections. The problem is there is no way to turn it off or on at a per connection level. So if you are knowingly going to connect to a server that has a non SNI valid cert you have to disable SNI for the whole VM. The default is whatever the VM is started with you can enable it by running this method.

      • disableSNI

        public static void disableSNI()
        Java 7 introduced SNI by default when you establish SSl connections. The problem is there is no way to turn it off or on at a per connection level. So if you are knowingly going to connect to a server that has a non SNI valid cert you have to disable SNI for the whole VM. The default is whatever the VM is started with you can disable it by running this method.
